Simon Munzert, Julia Ellingwood, Lisa Oswald, Richard Traunmüller

July 11, 2025

Abstract

Online platforms massively rely on automated systems to moderate hate speech, yet these systems are only as reliable as the human-labeled data on which they are trained. While much attention has been paid to the technical challenges of content moderation—such as the volume and complexity of online speech—we argue that a more fundamental issue lies in the subjectivity of what people perceive as hate speech. Using an original cross-national survey of 19,172 respondents across 11 countries in the Global North and South, we elicited over 150,000 content moderation decisions on synthetic but realistic social media vignettes. We find broad support for leaving non-threatening speech online, but also pervasive disagreement in judgments—driven not by identity or demographics, but by the respondent’s stance on the issue debated. This “myside bias” is large, comprehensive in affecting both perceptions and action preferences, consistent across political ideologies, measurable across a wide range of issues, and global in scope. Our findings underscore a key limitation of current moderation approaches: when judgments about harmful speech hinge on subjective political commitments, there can be no neutral or globally acceptable technical fix. These results have far-reaching implications for the design of content moderation systems and for the legitimacy of automated enforcement in polarized environments.

Hypotheses

Speech-respondent interactions (issue-based and identity-based myside bias)

H1: Respondents who agree (vs. disagree) with the issue position of the target are more likely to perceive messages as being hate speech and offensive speech, and to prefer platform, legal, and employer action against the message/sender.

H2: Respondents who share gender or ethnicity with the target are more likely to perceive messages as being hate speech and offensive speech, and to prefer platform, legal, and employer action against the message/sender.

H3: Respondents who share gender or ethnicity with the sender are less likely to perceive messages as being hate speech and offensive speech, and to prefer platform, legal, and employer action against the message/sender.

Framing experiment (sensitivity of moderation in different contexts)

H4: If the vignette evaluation is framed as a moderation task for a platform that promotes free speech and takes a critical stance against any form of censorship (vs. a neutral frame), respondents are less likely to prefer platform action against the message sender but are as likely to perceive messages as being hate speech and offensive speech, and to prefer legal action against the message/sender.

H5: If the vignette evaluation is framed as a moderation task for a platform that vows to protect vulnerable users from hate speech and takes an aggressive stance against hateful content on their pages (vs. a neutral frame), respondents are more likely to prefer platform action against the message sender but are as likely to perceive messages as being hate speech and offensive speech, and to prefer legal action against the message/sender.

Question order experiment (exposure effects of hate speech)

H6: If respondents are exposed to the vignette evaluation task before (vs. after) they get to answer questions about governance of speech, they are more willing to have speech restricted, and see more responsibility for action against hate speech in the hands of online services, lawmakers, the justice system, and employers.

Data collection

We conducted a cross-national online survey experiment in 12 countries: Brazil, Colombia, Germany, India, Indonesia, Nigeria, the Philippines, Poland, Turkey, the United Kingdom, and the United States. The survey was translated into the respective languages of each country. In addition to fielding an English questionnaire, we used a Hindi version in India and a Filipino version in the Philippines. The survey was designed to be completed in approximately 15 minutes.

Participants were recruited using Meta ads deployed on Facebook and Instagram. We used targeting based on age (18-40 and 41-65+ years). Following recommendations of Neundorf and Öztürk (2002), we used conversion as the campaign objective, which optimized ad delivery on respondents completing the survey. We selected “highest volume” as campaign bid strategy and used Advantage+ placements. The audiences consist of people living in the respective country, speaking the language to which the survey and ad had been translated.

We used two different ad versions. The neutral ad consisting of the text “Do you want to participate in our survey? Hertie School researchers want to hear your opinions.” and a neutral image of two pencils. A second ad consisted of the text “What should people be allowed to say on social media? Hertie School researchers want to hear your opinions.” and an image of a stop signaling hand in front of face. Once participants clicked on the “learn more” action button in the advertisement, they were directed to our survey, hosted on a Qualtrics page.

Data was collected from November 2022 to January 2023 until the campaign budget was exhausted. Before starting the survey, participants were informed about the length, objective and risks of the survey and they were be asked to provide explicit informed consent. Furthermore, participants were debriefed at the end of the survey.

Pre-analysis plan

The study was pre-registered on the Open Science Framework (OSF) at the following link: https://osf.io/2ec8m.

Vignette construction and delivery


Vignette attribute levels were assigned randomly. Vignette decks were balanced across several attribute values so that each respondent got to see a mix of vignettes that varied along message, sender, and target characteristics. Specific sender and target ethnicity characteristics were oversampled depending on the country context to account for prevalent ethnicities in the different settings.

The vignettes were constructed in a way that mimics short conversations on a popular social media platform. The conversations were manipulated along a set of target, sender, and message characteristics. Those include: (1) topic of the conversation, (2) target’s gender, (3) target’s ethnicity, (4) target’s topic stance, (5) sender’s gender, (6) sender’s ethnicity, (7) sender’s message target, (8) sender’s message type, (9) sender’s message severity.

The messages were generated by the researchers and adapted to the topic and country context by translators who were closely supervised during the process. Technical details of the vignette construction, sampling, as well as the raw material is documented in the vignette construction repository on OSF (https://osf.io/2ec8m).

Prior to exposing respondents to the set of hate speech vignettes, they were made aware of the nature of the content that they were about to see and encouraged to skip the task if they feel uncomfortable.
